00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 problemPanic.pl - Allow for a PANIC button that gives additional
00020                   hints, possibly costing some points.
00021 
00022 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00023 
00024 This file implements a mechanism for you to provide one or more "panic
00025 button" that your students can use to get additional hints, at the
00026 cost of a portion of their score.
00027 
00028 To include the button, use the command Panic::Button command within a
00029 BEGIN_TEXT/END_TEXT block.  E.g.,
00030 
00031     BEGIN_TEXT
00032     \{Panic::Button(label => "Request a Hint", penalty => .25)\}
00033     (you will lose 25% of your points if you do)
00034     END_TEXT
00035 
00036 When the student presses the hint button, the button will not longer
00037 be available, and the "panic level" will be increased.  This sets the
00038 variable $panicked, which you can use to determine whether to include the
00039 hints or not.  For example
00040 
00041     if ($panicked) {
00042       BEGIN_TEXT
00043         Hint:  You should factor the numerator and cancel
00044         one of the factors with the denominator.
00045       END_TEXT
00046     }
00047 
00048 Note that you can create a "cascade" of hints by including a second
00049 panic button in the hint received from the first button.  This will
00050 set $panic to 2 (panic level 2) and you can use that to include the
00051 second hint.
00052 
00053     if ($panicked) {
00054       BEGIN_TEXT
00055         Hint:  You should factor the numerator and cancel
00056         one of the factors with the denominator.
00057         $PAR
00058         \{Panic::Button(label => "Another Hint", penalty => .25)\}
00059         (costing an additional 25%)
00060       END_TEXT
00061       
00062       if ($panicked > 1) {
00063         BEGIN_TEXT
00064         Additional Hint: one of the factors is \(x+$a)\).
00065         END_TEXT
00066       }
00067     }
00068 
00069 You can add more buttons in a similar way.  You can not have separate
00070 buttons for separate hints that are NOT cascaded, however.  (That may
00071 be possible in future versions.)
00072 
00073 The Panic::Button command takes two optional parameters:
00074 
00075 =over
00076 
00077 =item S<C<< label => "text" >>>
00078 
00079 Sets the text to use for the button.  The default is "Request a Hint".
00080 
00081 =item S<C<< penalty => percent >>>
00082 
00083 Specifies the number points to lose (as a number from 0 to 1) if this
00084 hint is displayed.  When more than one panic button is used, the
00085 penalties are cumulative.  That is, two penalties of .25 would produce
00086 a total penalty of .5, so the student would lose half his points if
00087 both hints were given.
00088 
00089 =back
00090 
00091 Once a hint is displayed, the panic button for that hint will no
00092 longer be shown, and the hint will continue to be displayed as the
00093 student submits new answers.
00094 
00095 A professor will be given a "Reset problem hints" checkbox at the
00096 bottom of the problem, and can use that to request that the panic
00097 level be reset back to 0.  This also sets the score and the number of
00098 attempts back to 0 as well, so this effectively resets the problem to
00099 its original state.  This is intended for use primarily during problem
00100 development, but can be used to allow a student to get full credit for
00101 a problem even after he or she has asked for a hint.
00102 
00103 To allow the grading penalties to work, you must include the command
00104 
00105     Panic::GradeWithPenalty();
00106 
00107 in order to install the panic-button grader.  You should do this afer
00108 setting the grader that you want to use for the problem itself, as the
00109 panic grader will use the one that is installed at the time the
00110 Panic::GradWithPenalty command is issued.
00111 
00112 =cut
00113 
00114 sub _problemPanic_init {Panic::Init()}
00115 
00116 #
00117 #  The packge to contain the routines and data for the Panic buttons
00118 #
00119 package Panic;
00120 
00121 my $isTeX = 0;         # true in hardcopy mode
00122 my $allowReset = 0;    # true if a professor is viewing the problem
00123 my $buttonCount = 0;   # number of panic buttons displayed so far
00124 my @penalty = (0);     # accummulated penalty values
00125 my $grader;            # problem's original grader
00126 
00127 #
00128 #  Allow resets if permission level is high enough.
00129 #  Look up the panic level and reset it if needed.
00130 #  Save the panic level for the next time through.
00131 #
00132 sub Init {
00133   $main::permissionLevel = 0 unless defined $main::permissionLevel;
00134   $allowReset = $main::permissionLevel > $main::PRINT_FILE_NAMES_PERMISSION_LEVEL;
00135   $isTeX = ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX');
00136   unless ($isTeX) {
00137     $main::panicked = $main::inputs_ref->{_panicked} || 0;
00138     $main::panicked = 0 if $main::inputs_ref->{_panic_reset} && $allowReset;
00139     main::TEXT(qq!<input type="hidden" name="_panicked" id="_panicked" value="$main::panicked" />!);
00140     main::RECORD_FORM_LABEL("_panicked");
00141   }
00142 }
00143 
00144 #
00145 #  Place a panic button on the page, if it's not hardcopy mode and its not at the wrong level.
00146 #  You can set the label, the penalty for taking this hint, and the panic level for this button.
00147 #  Use submitAnswers if it is before the due date, and checkAnswers otherwise.
00148 #
00149 sub Button {
00150   $buttonCount++;
00151   my %options = (
00152     label => "Request a Hint",
00153     level => $buttonCount,
00154     penalty => 0,
00155     @_
00156   );
00157   my $label = $options{label};
00158   my $level = $options{level};
00159   $penalty[$buttonCount] = $penalty[$buttonCount-1] + $options{penalty};
00160   $penalty[$buttonCount] = 1 if $penalty[$buttonCount] > 1;
00161   return if $isTeX || $main::panicked >= $level;
00162   my $time = time();
00163   my $name = ($main::openDate <= $time && $time <= $main::dueDate ? "submitAnswers" : "checkAnswers");
00164   $value = quoteHTML($value);
00165   return qq!<input type="submit" name="$name" value="$label" onclick="document.getElementById('_panicked').value++">!;
00166 }
00167 
00168 #
00169 #  The reset button
00170 #
00171 sub ResetButton {
00172   main::RECORD_FORM_LABEL("_panic_reset");
00173   return qq!<input type="checkbox" name="_panic_reset"> Reset problem hints!;
00174 }
00175 
00176 #
00177 #  Handle HTML in the value
00178 #
00179 sub quoteHTML {
00180   my $string = shift;
00181   $string =~ s/&/\&amp;/g; $string =~ s/"/\&quot;/g;
00182   $string =~ s/>/\&gt;/g;  $string =~ s/</\&lt;/g;
00183   return $string;
00184 }
00185 
00186 #
00187 #  Install the panic grader, saving the original one
00188 #
00189 sub GradeWithPenalty {
00190   $grader = $main::PG->{flags}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} || \&main::avg_problem_grader;
00191   main::install_problem_grader(\&Panic::grader);
00192 }
00193 
00194 #
00195 #  The grader for the panic levels.
00196 #
00197 sub grader {
00198   #
00199   #  Save the old score and call the original grader.
00200   #  Compute the penalized score, and save it, if it is better than the old score.
00201   #  Reset the values if we are resetting scores.
00202   #
00203   my $oldScore = $_[1]->{recorded_score} || 0;
00204   my ($result,$state) = &{$grader}(@_);
00205   $result->{score} *= 1-$penalty[$main::panicked];
00206   $state->{recorded_score} = ($result->{score} > $oldScore ? $result->{score} : $oldScore);
00207   $state->{recorded_score} = $state->{num_of_incorrect_ans} = $state->{num_of_correct_ans} = 0
00208     if $main::inputs_ref->{_panic_reset} && $allowReset;
00209 
00210   #
00211   #  Add the problemPanic message and data
00212   #
00213   $result->{type} = "problemPanic ($result->{type})";
00214   if ($main::panicked) {
00215     $result->{msg} .= '</i><p><b>Note:</b> <i>' if $result->{msg};
00216     $result->{msg} .= 'Your score was reduced by '.(int($penalty[$main::panicked]*100)).'%'
00217                    .  ' because you accepted '.($main::panicked == 1 ? 'a hint.' : $main::panicked.' hints.');
00218     #
00219     #  Add the reset checkbox, if needed
00220     #
00221     $result->{msg} .= '<p>'.ResetButton() if $allowReset;
00222   }
00223 
00224   return ($result,$state);
00225 }
